tn.text: John continues to describe the events that happened before the throne of God. The Lamb begins to open the seals on the scroll.
This is a command to one person, apparently the rider of the white horse who is spoken of in verse 2.

This kind of crown was a likeness of wreaths of olive branches or laurel leaves, probably hammered out in gold. Examples actually made of leaves were given to victorious athletes to wear on their heads. This can be translated with an active verb. AT: "he received a crown" or "God gave him a crown (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This was a wreath of olive branches or of laurel leaves like the wreaths that winning athletes received in contests at the time of John.
"the next seal" or "seal number two" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"the next living creature" or "living creature number two" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"it was red like fire" or "it was bright red"

tn.ref: To its rider was given permission
tn.text: This can be stated with an active verb. AT: "God gave permission to its rider" or "Its rider received person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: This rider was given a huge sword
tn.text: This can be stated with an active verb. AT: "This rider received a huge sword" or "God gave this rider a huge sword" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"the next seal" or "seal number three" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"the next living creature" or "living creature number three" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
a tool used for weighing things

tn.ref: A choenix of wheat for one denarius
tn.text: Some languages might want a verb such as "cost" or "buy" in the sentence. AT: "A choenix of wheat now costs one denarius" or "Buy a choenix of wheat with one denarius" There was very little wheat for all the people, so its price was very high.
This refers to a specific measure that was about one liter. AT: "one liter" or "one bowl" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
This coin was worth a day's wages. AT: "one silver coin" or "the pay for one day of work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])

tn.ref: But do not harm the oil and the wine
tn.text: If the oil and wine were harmed, there would be less of them for people to buy, and their prices would go up.
These expressions probably stand for the olive oil harvest and the grape harvest. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the next seal" or "seal number four" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"the next living creature" or "living creature number four" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"grey." This is the color of a dead body, so its color is a symbol of death.

fourth of the earth** - The earth here represents the people of the earth. AT: "one-fourth" of the people on the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_fraction]])
A sword is a weapon, and here it represents war. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: with the wild animals of the earth
tn.text: This means that Death and Hades would cause the wild animals to attack and kill people.
"the next seal" or "seal number five" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
This may have been "at the base of the altar."
This can be translated with an active verb. AT "those whom others had killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the word of God and the testimony
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the testimony is God's witness to the truth of his word (as shown in the UDB), or 2) the testimony is the believers' witness to the truth of God's word.
Believing the word of God and the testimony is spoken of as if they were objects that could be physically held in one's hands. AT: "which they believed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word blood here represents their deaths. AT: "punish those who killed us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: until the full number ... were to be killed
tn.text: This implies that God had decided that a certain number of people should be killed by their enemies.

tn.ref: their fellow servants and their brothers and sisters
tn.text: This is one group of people described in two ways: as servants and as brothers and sisters. AT: "their brothers and sisters who serve God with them" or "their fellow believers who serve God with them"
Christians are often spoken of as being one another's brothers and sisters. AT: "fellow Christians" or "fellow believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the next seal" or "seal number six" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

Sometimes sackcloth was made of black hair. People would wear sackcloth when they were mourning. The image of sackcloth is meant to lead people to think of death and mourning. AT: "as black as mourning clothes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The image of blood is meant to lead people to think of death. How it was like blood can be stated clearly. AT: "red like blood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: just as a fig tree drops its unripe fruit when shaken by a stormy wind
tn.text: "just as unripened fruit easily falls in great quantities from a fig tree when a strong wind shakes it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: The sky vanished like a scroll that was being rolled up
tn.text: The sky was normally thought of as being strong like a sheet of metal, but now it was weak like a sheet of paper and easily torn and rolled up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This word refers to the warriors who command in the battle.
large holes in the sides of hill
This refers to God. They did not want God to see them and punish them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "face" is used for the idea of "presence." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the great day of their wrath has come
tn.text: The day of their wrath refers to the time when they would punish wicked people.  AT: "this is the terrible time when they will punish people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Existing now is spoken of as having come. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Their" refers to the one on the throne and the Lamb.

Surviving, or staying alive, is spoken of as standing.  This question is used to express their great sadness and fear that no one will be able to survive when God punishes them. AT: "No one can survive" (See: (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
